div.p: The idea of a structured requirements specification list for an encoding scheme like MEI, consisting of a reasonable order of musical features that have to be addressed by the new encoding format was born during the workshop in Charlottesville in July 2009. The collected examples from all fields which MEI was expected to cover should be arrangend in an order of increasing complexity and in a form which facilitates understanding. A mixture of examples (preferably with coexisting facsimiles) each with a short discussion of what notational/musicological problem is exemplified and some discussion of how MEI can solve the problem was envisaged. Later on a direct link to a collection of MEI encodings should be added.

The preliminary collection of examples gathered in the context of the Charlottesville meeting needed a structural approach before being augmented by numerous new ones. A small sub-group of the MEI Council (Eleanor Selfridge-Field, Donald Byrd, and Joachim Veit) intensively dealt with this problem. Several lists, including the famous Byrd & Isaacson list A Music Representation Requirement Specification for Academia (first published in Computer Music Journal 2003, last revision after the Detmold workshop in April 2010 as Version 2.1a), and Selfridge-Field's list which was based on the so-called Dagstuhl Core as well as her comprehensive structured collection of examples and Veit's preliminary wiki-collection circulated and have been discussed. The final structure chosen for the MEI website should be connected with the MEI example-encodings but at the same time not primarily being based on the technical requirements but on a pedagocical approach to the field of notation and editing. The structure presented here is a sort of compromise between several possible approaches and should not be regarded as a final fixation. During the following phase of the integration and augmentation of examples the need for some revisions certainly will turn up. The group decided to keep the chapters „Notation forms beyond CMN“, „The role of facsimiles“, „Analytical and eductational features“ as well as „Sound aspects“ for later attention because chapters I and III already imply a lot of necessary work.

The sub-group is very grateful to all members of the Council who contributed with a lot of examples and with their discussions to the progress of our endeavours. At the same time we sincerely invite all people interested in the MEI-development to contribute to the growth of the collection by posting further examples.
